texts.shortText:
Sea fans are characterized by having a stiff inner skeleton made of a horn-like protein called gorgonin. This is covered by an often brightly-pigmented layer of living tissue from which small, retractable polyps emerge. Each polyp has 8 pinnate (feathery) tentacles.

This species has a sparsely-branched form with just a few ‘twigs’ that are not arranged into a fan. The branches are densely covered on all sides by small polyps that tend to contrast in colour to the main stems and which usually emerge from distinct swellings (hence ‘warty’ common name). Common colours are yellow or white polyps on red stems, or white polyps on grey stems.
Colonies typically 300-400 mm tall mm, branches 3-5 mm wide.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Sodwana.

On rocky reefs in depth of about 20-180 m, often on flat rocks subject to sand inundation. Uncommon and very little else know about the biology. Definitely occurs form Cape Agulhas eastwards but the records form False Bay are not supported by reference specimens.
Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.

Colonies spread by budding new polyps from the tips and broken fragments can develop into new colonies if deposited in suitable habitats. Details of sexual reproduction are unknown for this species, but other sea-fans have separate male and female colonies and release sperm and eggs into the water. These merge to form planktonic larvae which settle and grow into new colonies.

Could be confused with the common Multicoloured sea fan Melithaea rubra, which is also small with thin branches, has the polyps each emerging from a distinct bump on the stem and comes a wide range of colours. However, that species usually forms dense tangled clumps mixed with other sessile invertebrates, and not simple twig-like colonies.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 32).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 48).

Velimerov, B (1971). Beitrag zur Systematik der sudafrikanischen Gorgonarien. Zoologischer Anzeiger, 187(3/4), 266-273.

Williams, GC (1992). The Alcyonacea of southern Africa. Gorgonian octocorals (Coelenterata, Anthozoa). Annals of the South African Museum, 101(8), 181-296. (p. 189).
